node.title: Can Hydrogen Save Aviation’s Fuel Challenges? It’s Got a Way to Go.
node.description: Small, experimental hydrogen-powered planes are paving the way for net-zero carbon aviation by 2050. But the route is rocky.
node.content: ["A fully fueled Boeing 787-10 Dreamliner can fly roughly 8,000 miles while ferrying 300 or so passengers and their luggage. A battery with the energy equivalent to that fuel would weigh about 6.6 million pounds. That\u2019s why \u2014 despite environmental advantages \u2014 we don\u2019t have battery-powered electric airliners.", "But aviation companies working to make cleaner aircraft are exploring the use of hydrogen, the world\u2019s most abundant element, to power both electric and combustion engines \u2014 and to make air travel more eco-friendly", "Hydrogen-powered planes are already aloft, although mostly as small, experimental aircraft. Yet those planes are helping to pave the way for net-zero carbon aviation by 2050, the goal set by many government and environmental groups. But hydrogen isn\u2019t without controversy: For now, it\u2019s expensive, not always green, and some say dangerous.", "\u201cThere are three ways of using hydrogen as fuel onboard an aircraft,\u201d said Amanda Simpson, who leads green initiatives for the aircraft manufacturer Airbus. Hydrogen can be a source of power for batterylike fuel cells, in hybrid aircraft, or as combustible fuel.", "Alternative-fuel technologies are well established in the automotive world, of course. Cars that burn alternative fuels \u2014 remember diesels converted to burn used French-fry oil? \u2014 have been around since the earliest days of horseless carriages. And hybrid gas and electric cars, such as the Toyota Prius, have been available since 1997. But only a few models, including the Toyota Mirai and the Hyundai Nexo, use hydrogen fuel cells.", "When Val Miftakhov founded ZeroAvia to develop electric aircraft, he first considered battery power. A Siberian \u00e9migr\u00e9 and physicist, his earlier start-up converted gasoline cars to electric, then incorporated an improved charging system. But batteries can sustain only the shortest excursions, like training flights. \u201cWhere a mission is an hour, batteries might work,\u201d he said. Battery-powered trainers also exist, such as the Pipistrel Alfa Electro which claims a one-hour flight time.", "ZeroAvia instead chose fuel cells, which are essentially a chemical battery that substitutes lighter-than-air hydrogen for the weighty lithium ion. Hydrogen is notable for its energy density \u2014 the amount of energy per kilogram \u2014 which is about three times that of jet fuel. The byproduct of burning hydrogen is water. Hydrogen can be made from water and renewable energy, although most is now made from natural gas, which is not particularly green.", "Mr. Miftakhov acknowledged that hydrogen storage containers, which were generally designed for ground transportation, were not practical for aircraft. \u201cWe need to focus on reducing the weight,\u201d he said, \u201cWe have some fairly low-hanging fruit.\u201d", "Unlike electric batteries, hydrogen fuel cells can be recharged in minutes, but there is a lack of fueling stations, and building them would be a huge undertaking.", "That problem is less critical for hybrid aircraft, which use a combination of electric and combustion power, said Pat Anderson, a professor of Aerospace Engineering at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University. \u201cIt can pull up to a fuel pump that exists today and fill up,\u201d he said.", "Mr. Anderson\u2019s students used a hybrid system in a 2011 eco-flight competition. They didn\u2019t win, but it sold Mr. Anderson on the merits of hybrid power engines, which he now builds at VerdeGo Aero, a Florida company that counts Erik Lindbergh, an X-Prize Foundation board member and Charles Lindbergh\u2019s grandson, as executive chairman.", "Modern hybrid systems can use a variable mix of electric and combustion power, and can even use the combustion motor as an electric generator in flight. It may give planes more range than battery or fuel cells alone, Mr. Anderson said.", "Whatever the power source, there are some advantages specific to electric engines, said Roei Ganzarski, who leads two companies: MagniX, which makes electric propulsion systems for aircraft, and Eviation which is developing the futuristic-looking Alice electric aircraft. One advantage is cost.", "\u201cAirplanes today are really, really expensive, and the main reason is the engines,\u201d he said. They require a lot of maintenance and consume a lot of expensive fuel. \u201cI can reduce the operating cost of that plane around 40 to 50 percent on average,\u201d he claimed. That\u2019s because electric motors are comparatively maintenance free.", "Harbour Air, which bills itself as \u201cthe world\u2019s largest seaplane airline,\u201d is seeking permission to carry passengers on its MagniX electric-powered de Havilland dhc-2 Beaver. A 10-passenger Cessna Grand has also flown with a MagniX engine.", "There are some things electric power cannot achieve, like lifting that 787. But that doesn\u2019t mean big jets can\u2019t go green, or at least greener. Several fuel refiners and airlines are experimenting with Sustainable Aviation Fuels, known as SAFs. These fuels, which burn just like the common \u201cJet A\u201d fuel, can be made from waste such as used cooking fats. Some companies, like Neste, use hydrogen in refining its SAF fuel.", "Although aviation safety organizations allow commercial aircraft to use fuel containing 50 percent or less SAF, in demonstrations, existing jets have burned 100-percent SAF, \u201cand the engines are very happy with it,\u201d Ms. Simpson of Airbus said.", "But SAF may be seen as a stopgap, as larger planes have flown happily burning emissions-free pure hydrogen. In 1957, a Martin B-57B powered part of a flight using hydrogen as fuel. In 1988, a Soviet TU-155 airliner flew on hydrogen fuel alone.", "For Senator Spark Matsunaga, a Democrat of Hawaii who died in 1990, it was a missed opportunity \u2014 as significant as Soviet\u2019s Sputnik satellite beating the United States into space. \u201cOnce again we\u2019ve missed the boat,\u201d he said, \u201cand we can only hope that the next administration will be more interested in hydrogen than this one has been.\u201d", "Any mention of hydrogen aircraft means addressing the zeppelin in the room. Although hydrogen has been used in ballooning since 1783, its aeronautical future dimmed on May 6, 1937, when the zeppelin Hindenburg very publicly burned in Lakehurst, N.J. killing 36. It is still debated if the flames, immortalized on radio and in newsreels (and a Led Zeppelin album cover), were caused mostly by hydrogen or the incendiary paint used on the airship\u2019s fabric skin. Regardless, the damage to hydrogen\u2019s reputation lingers today.", "More recently, ZeroAvia experienced a bad news/good news scenario when its hydrogen-fuel-cell-powered Piper Malibu Mirage M350 crash landed last April. The good news was that no one was hurt, despite the plane losing a wing. Better still, with no fuel to leak and no hot engine to ignite it, there was no Hindenburg-like conflagration.", "\u201cThe hydrogen system itself all held up perfectly,\u201d Mr. Miftakhov said. \u201cThe emergency crew said if it were a fossil-fuel plane it would have been a major fire.\u201d", "But the big argument against hydrogen has not been safety but cost. Although \u201cgreen\u201d hydrogen can be produced with water and renewable energy, most produced now is so-called \u201cgray hydrogen\u201d made using fossil fuels, which is not much cleaner than burning those fuels themselves.", "Hydrogen proponents say that technological improvements and larger scale facilities could bring the cost down to $1 per kilogram, the point at which it is competitive with fossil fuel. Part of the Biden administration\u2019s \u201cEarthshots\u201d initiative is a proposed $400 million investment in 2022 toward reaching the $1 per kilogram mark within 10 years.", "Hydrogen boosters like Mr. Ganzarski argue that while green hydrogen may initially be costly to make, the cost of not pursuing hydrogen aircraft may be greater. It is with some understatement that he said, \u201cEmissions are not good for our health.\u201d"]
